Life, Loss, and Letting Go: A Simpler Perspective

Kenji

hat does it mean to truly move on? What does it mean to let go of the things that weigh us down? These are big questions, but often, the answers are surprisingly simple.

At its heart, life is about change. Yet, we resist change because we hold onto expectations — about others, about outcomes, and even about ourselves. We expect things to follow a certain path, and when they don’t, we feel hurt or stuck. The truth is, trying to control the uncontrollable only adds to our suffering.

This applies not only to relationships but also to our emotions. We tend to label emotions like sadness or anger as “bad,” but they’re not. They are simply messengers, highlighting what needs attention or adjustment. When we resist these feelings, they linger. When we accept them, they transform.

The Role of Acceptance

Letting go doesn’t mean forgetting or pretending the past didn’t happen. It’s not about erasing pain or undoing mistakes. It’s about learning to accept what has already passed. We only deepen our struggle by fighting to hold on or control what’s no longer here. True freedom comes from acknowledging reality and making peace with it.

How to Begin Letting Go

Beyond Relationships

This isn’t just about love or grief. It applies to missed opportunities, unmet expectations, and even personal setbacks. Letting go is about making space for growth and moving forward with clarity.

Life is always changing, like water flowing in a stream. The harder we try to block it, the more we disrupt its natural course. But when we stop resisting, we allow things to settle, and peace becomes possible.

A New Way to Look at It

Letting go isn’t about forcing yourself to move on. It’s about accepting that some things have already passed and living with that truth.

What About You? Is there something you’ve been holding onto?
